title: Modeling Tabular Running Track with Slope Field

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “D of t, in meters.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. D of t is 0. Column 2. t is 8. D of t is 1500. Column 3. t is 16. D of t is 2800. Column 4. t is 24. D of t is 3900. Column 2. t is 32. D of t is 5000." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>24</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>32</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(meters)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1500</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2800</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3900</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5000</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student on the school track and field team is running laps around a track. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>32</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total distance run, in meters, is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="D of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with the two subintervals indicated by the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 32, of, D of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “D of t, in meters.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. D of t is 0. Column 2. t is 8. D of t is 1500. Column 3. t is 16. D of t is 2800. Column 4. t is 24. D of t is 3900. Column 2. t is 32. D of t is 5000." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>24</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>32</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(meters)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1500</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2800</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3900</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5000</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student on the school track and field team is running laps around a track. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>32</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total distance run, in meters, is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="D of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with the two subintervals indicated by the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 32, of, D of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>32</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(b) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 16, of, D prime of, open parenthesis, 2 t, close parenthesis, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(c) Using correct units, approximate <math alttext="D prime of 16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="8 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Explain the meaning of <math alttext="D prime of 16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(e) It is known that <math alttext="D prime of 24, equals 140" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>140</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="y equals D of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) It is known that <math alttext="D double prime of t, is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="24 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 31" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>24</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>31</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. If <math alttext="D of 30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximated using the equation from part (e), would the approximation be an overestimate or underestimate for the actual value of <math alttext="D of 30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(g) A second student is raising funds by running laps for <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total number of laps run by this student is modeled by <math alttext="L of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, a differentiable function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. For each lap run, the student raises <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dollars. Write an expression for the rate of change, in dollars per minute, of the total money raised at time <math alttext="t equals 45" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

(h) Explain why the following slope field cannot represent the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to t, equals 0.25 y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
